items.content_html: Stephen Hawking‚Äôs death was the first notable death since 2009 that I did not learn first about on Twitter. I‚Äôm relying on The NY Times and WaPo for news now. I didn‚Äôt have to figure out from hearsay and later research who it was and whether it was true.

I feel like hardly any apps use the iOS 11 Files app integration that Apple introduced last year. Google searches haven‚Äôt yielded much information on any limitations of the API that are of interest to me. I guess I have to try to do what I want and see if it works.
The third nor‚Äôeaster in three weeks has screwed up our plans yet again.

items.title: Apple buying Texture
items.content_html: Apple buying Texture is interesting and unexpected to me. I subscribed to Texture for a couple weeks and did not like it because I found it too hard to read on my iPad and iPhone. Basically, for most of the magazines it offers, it provides you images of magazines, with their crazy layouts and scads of advertisements, rather than access to the magazine‚Äôs website content. It was like reading a PDF rather than a webpage. The small text size, traditional print magazine layout, and the need to pan around the page made the reading experience very poor. Since it looked good, I am not sure if Apple will spend much time improving it, even though it was impossible to use.
I realized this morning that what I was coding last night was an implementation of the Strategy pattern. And I thought I had just made it up myself. üòÇ
My son has figured out how to turn on the flashlight of my Apple Watch. No wonder battery life took a hit lately. üòÄ
My wife let me sleep in today. üôèüòÄüëç‚ù§Ô∏è
Blog post: My slide into audiophile territory, Part 2‚ÄîWhat does it mean, to me, to be an audiophile?
üéµ I have become a huge Lana Del Rey fan recently. I can‚Äôt get enough of her lushly produced dream pop. (Maybe I‚Äôm depressed or something. üòÇ)
Blog post: SwiftoDo Development Notes, March 2018
Based on the MacBook Pro keyboard-related gripes of Daniel Jalkut and the guys on the ATP podcast, I‚Äôm considering buying an iMac instead of a new MacBook Pro next year. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

üéµ ‚ÄúIf I had my time again‚Äù is my favorite song from Tim Minchin‚Äôs ‚ÄúGroundhog Day‚Äù musical. I love how it flips the premise of the show on its head for a bit and lets the female lead shine.
SwiftoDo 2.9.2 is now available in the App Store. It adds a filter option for prioritized or non-prioritized tasks, optimizes app startup, and fixes some minor bugs.
Thundersnow!
Judging by the nearly mashed-up news headlines, I think that The Weather Channel missed an opportunity to name today‚Äôs storm ‚ÄúWinter Stormy Daniels‚Äù.

Swift, multi-threading, closures, callbacks, and UI-blocking alert controllers are colliding in unexpected ways and kicking my ass this week. I‚Äôm stashing my latest bug fix, which isn‚Äôt finished, and building a new SwiftoDo release from my prior commit.
Google Voice‚Äôs voicemail transcriptions can be chilling sometimes.

I have to create dozens of Active Directory user accounts on a domain controller today, and the PowerShell cmdlets to help with that are somehow not installed. Time to get some ‚òïÔ∏è and power through it.

My daughter has trouble falling asleep. This past week she has started to complain about noise outside. It turns out you can hear airplane noise from her room constantly. We live 30 miles from the airport, so this is a bit surprising to me. I wonder if flight paths have been changed or something.
Hi, @orionp. I heard your interview on The Omni Show. You are a very interesting fellow!

We all survived the six hour blackout tonight. It was cold but we were able to get pizza delivered and to spend a couple hours with nearby friends how have a generator. Still, we are grateful for lights and a warm house.
I actually solved a user‚Äôs problem with my iOS app today by asking ‚Äúhave you tried turning it off and on again?‚Äù üòÖ.

SwiftoDo 2.9.1 is now available in the App Store. It fixes a longstanding Dropbox-related bug that caused a crash on startup for some users. Bonus feature: the task editor now recognizes new projects and contexts and adds them to their respective pickers.

This is the best explanation I‚Äôve found for why Excel outputs my graph series in the opposite order I want them, every time I create a sideways bar chart. It‚Äôs an insane default. Typical Microsoft brutalist design!
The light-to-dark progression in my app screenshots is oddly satisfying to me tonight.
